content:
• Wednesday, February 15, 2017
  • SSC-OLD

    Wecast Network -15.7% after bearish Street Sweeper take

    • Wecast Network (WCST) slipped 15.7% today, and briefly fell as much as 30%, after a bearish article from Seeking Alpha contributor The Street Sweeper.
    • The stock's surge -- it jumped 74% in the first week of February -- is because of "silly announcements" of merger deals with companies run by its chairman Bruno Wu. The moves amount to a "rat's nest" of related-party deals, The Street Sweeper says.
    • The company also saw departures from top leadership, including the company's CEO and CFO in recent months.
    • "Institutions avoid Wecast stock, while losses persist, cash dwindles, the deficit exceeds $92 million and Wecast struggles along under going concern issues," the piece says.
    • It's "blowing up" and "when the smoke clears, we expect the stock to simmer down to 20 cents per share."
    • Shares closed today on Nasdaq at $1.50.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:17 PM | 7 Comments
  • NTES

    NetEase +6% after Q4 beat on strong revenue gains

    • NetEase (NTES +2.2%) has picked up 6% after hours as its Q4 earnings easily beat expectations with sharp revenue gains for the quarter and the year.
    • Mobile games were the key strength, and the company introduced more than 40 new titles last year.
    • Growth in gross profits came from revenue contributions in mobile games including Onmyoji and New Ghost, as well as its licensed versions of Blizzard's Overwatch and World of Warcraft.
    • Revenue breakout: Online game services, 8.96B yuan (up 63%); Advertising services, 664.8M yuan (up 9.2%); E-mail, e-commerce and others, 2.48B yuan (up 38.1%).
    • Gross profit margin for online games was 60.7%, down from the prior year's 67.2%, thanks to an increase in the mix from lower-margin mobile and licensed games.
    • Conference call to come at 8 p.m. ET.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 6:56 PM | 9 Comments
  • GOLD

    Barrick Gold +2% on Q4 beat, dividend hike, stronger balance sheet

    • Barrick Gold (ABX) +2.1% AH after beating expectations for Q4 earnings and revenues, raising its dividend and strengthening its balance sheet.
    • ABX says its mines generated free cash flow of $1.51B, a company record, and cut total debt by $2B, or 20%.
    • The company has been selling non-core assets to help reduce deb, and now says it plans to cut debt by another $2.9B by year-end 2018, with half the reduction in 2017, which would cut the total debt load to $5B from $7.9B currently.
    • In 2016, ABX produced 5.52M oz. of gold, at a cost of sales applicable to gold of $798/oz. and all-in sustaining costs of $730/oz., a 12% Y/Y reduction; Q4 gold production totaled 1.52M oz. at a cost of sales applicable to gold of $784/oz. and all-in sustaining costs of $732/oz.
    • ABX forecasts 2017 production of 5.6M-5.9M oz. of gold at a cost of sales applicable to gold of $780-$820/oz., and all-in sustaining costs of $720-$770/oz., an improvement over previous guidance of 5M-5.5M oz. at all-in sustaining costs of $740-$790/oz.
    • ABX plans to expand exploration beyond core districts and projects, with ~80% of its $185M-$225M exploration budget earmarked for the Americas and much of the remainder for Africa.
    • The company also reports progress on projects with the potential to contribute up to 1.1M oz. of gold production at Cortez, Goldrush, Lagunas Norte and Turquoise Ridge.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:32 PM | 8 Comments
  • NTES

    NetEase beats by $0.86, beats on revenue

  • HGG

    Hhgregg +21% as it sets plan to explore strategic alternatives

    • Hhgregg (HGG -4.6%) is rocketing after hours, up 21%, after a filing saying it's engaged Stifel Financial (SF +2.1%) units to "pursue a range of potential strategic and financial transactions."
    • Stifel Nicolaus is engaged as financial adviser, and Stifel unit Miller Buckfire as investment banker.
    • Hhgregg hasn't set a timetable for the process.
    • “We are committed to improving our results through our business strategy, including investments made to shift our focus to appliances and furniture, and additional expected cost reductions,” says CEO Robert Riesbeck. "We believe it is an appropriate time to explore potential strategic transactions. "
     
     
     
     
    | 6:02 PM | 17 Comments

  • SNPS

    Synopsys +5.64%; Q1 2017 report, Q2 and FY outlook positive

    • Q1 2017 results – revenue $652.8M (+14.8% Y/Y, $15.07M above estimates), EPS $0.94 ($0.16 above estimates), net income $145.1M (vs. $105.9M Y/Y)
    • Q2 2017 projections – revenue $665M-$680M (consensus $638.93M), EPS $0.85-$0.88 (consensus $0.77) expenses $507M-$517M, other income and expense -$1M to $1M, normalized annual tax rate applied in net income calculations 19%, fully diluted outstanding shares 152M-155M
    • FY 2017 projections – revenue $2.58B-$2.61B (consensus $2.59B), EPS $3.21-$3.26 (consensus $3.20), other income and expense $2M-$6M, normalized annual tax rate applied in net income calculations 19%, fully diluted outstanding shares 152M-155M, cash flow from operations $500M-$520M
    • Synopsys chairman and co-CEO Aart de Geus: "The first fiscal quarter was an excellent beginning to the year, as we substantially exceeded expectations. Business was strong across the board, amplified by the timing of hardware and IP deliverables. Our first quarter results and confidence in the year lead us to increase annual revenue, earnings per share and operating cash flow targets. In addition, we continued to return capital to shareholders with a $100 million share repurchase. Meanwhile, semiconductor and systems companies, as well as software developers across industries, continue to invest in many of the areas that enable the era of 'smart everything,' and our Silicon to Software vision and portfolio set us apart as a highly valued partner in these efforts."
    • After hours – (NASDAQ:SNPS) $70
    • Conference call
    • Press release
     
     
     
     
    | 5:33 PM
  • EQIX

    Equinix -2.8% after guiding to low side

    • Equinix (NASDAQ:EQIX) is off 2.8% following a Q4 earnings report that featured downbeat forecasts for the upcoming quarter.
    • It guided to Q1 revenues of $940M-$946M (below consensus for $964M), cash gross margins of 67-68%, and adjusted EBITDA of $421M-$427M (below consensus for $453M). For the full year, it sees revenues of $3.93B (below consensus for $4.09B) and EBITDA of more than $1.84B (vs. expected $1.92B).
    • For Q4, the company beat profit expectations and posted record quarterly bookings. In 2016, adjusted FFO was up 30% to $1.078B.
    • The company boosted its dividend by more than 14%, to $2/share quarterly.
    • Conference call to come at 5:30 p.m. ET.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 5:12 PM | 1 Comment

    • NGL Energy Partners (NYSE:NGL) -4.7% AH after announcing a public offering of 8M comon units, with an underwriters option to purchase up to an additional 1.2M shares.
    • NGL says it plans to use the proceeds to reduce borrowings under its senior secured revolving credit facility.

  • SPWR

    SunPower -5.5% after guiding Q1 revenues below consensus

    • SunPower (NASDAQ:SPWR) -5.5% AH after posting a bigger than expected Q4 loss on 19% lower revenues, and issuing downside guidance for Q1 revenues.
    • SPWR sees Q1 revenues of $370M-$420M vs. $459M analyst consensus estimate, as well as gross margin of 0-2% and 150-180 MW deployed.
    • SPWR reaffirms revenue guidance for the full year, seeing FY 2017 revenues of $2.1B-$2.6B vs. consensus, with 1.3-1.6 GW deployed.
    • Despite current industry conditions, the company forecasts positive adjusted EBITDA for the full year, weighted toward H2.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:58 PM | 14 Comments
  • MOH

    Molina Healthcare Q4 top line up 15%; earnings down 403%; cash flow ops down 82%; shares off 13% after hours

    • Net Income: (91) (-403.3%); Non-GAAP Net Income: (86) (-360.6%); Loss/Share: (1.64) (-415.4%); Non-GAAP Loss/Share: (1.54) (-365.5%); Cash Flow Ops: 40 (-81.7%).

  • MMLP

    Martin Midstream to launch 2.6M-unit offering

    • Martin Midstream Partners (NASDAQ:MMLP) -2.4% AH after announcing a public offering of 2.6M common units, with an underwriters option to purchase up to an additional 390K units.
    • MMLP says it plans to use the proceeds to pay for part of the acquisition of an asphalt terminal facility in Hondo, Tex., from Martin Resource Management, as well as to pay down debt and for general partnership purposes.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:24 PM | 12 Comments
  • NTAP

    NetApp +8%; Q3 2017 report, Q4 outlook midpoint over expectations

    • Q3 2017 results – revenue $1.4B (+0.7% Y/Y, $10M above estimates), EPS $0.82 ($0.08 above estimates), net income $231M (vs. $206M Y/Y), cash, cash equivalents and investments $4.6B, cash from operations $235M, share repurchases and dividends $336M
    • Highlights – all-flash array annualized net revenue run rate $1.4B (+160% Y/Y), petabytes of flash shipped approximately 300, Clustered Data ONTAP running 50% of installed base capacity
    • Q4 2017 projections – revenue $1.365B-$1.515B (consensus $1.4B), EPS $0.79-$0.84 (consensus $0.78)
    • NetApp CEO George Kurian: "The transformation of NetApp is yielding solid results and has changed the trajectory of our business. With our industry-leading portfolio of solutions and Data Fabric strategy, NetApp is well positioned to lead in the next era of IT."
    • After hours – (NASDAQ:NTAP) $42

  • NBLX

    Noble Midstream hits 52-week high following string of positive news

    • Noble Midstream Partners (NBLX +3.1%) pushes to a new 52-week high, continuing its advance following Monday's news that it is forming a 50/50 joint venture with Plains All American Pipeline to acquire Advantage Pipeline.
    • NBLX also reported better than expected Q4 earnings and 34% higher revenues Y/Y, while guiding 2017 distribution per unit growth of 20% and distributable cash flow coverage of 1.7x-1.9x.
    • Mizuho reiterates its Buy rating and raises its price target for the shares by $4 to $51 to reflect the strong guidance and Delaware Basin expansion, believing NBLX is well positioned to post 20% distribution growth with healthy coverage through 2020.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:50 PM
  • YY

    YY rips, up 10% to highest point since October

    • YY is on the move today, up 10% now, on more than triple average volume.
    • Volume has been fairly steady today on no apparent news.
    • The company was upgraded by crowd-sentiment firm Vetr to Strong Buy with 100% of its users bullish.
    • Vetr users have a target price of $51.93, now implying 7% upside from today's sharply higher price.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:36 PM | 25 Comments
  • ANET

    Analysts foreseeing steady execution in Cisco Systems earnings

    • Don't expect "fireworks" in Cisco Systems' (CSCO +1.6%) fiscal Q2 earnings report after the closing bell, says Drexel Hamilton -- "just more execution."
    • And perhaps some color on an acquisition of AppDynamics in the 11th hour before that company planned to go public.
    • Switching and routing will keep weighing on results, says the firm's Brian White: He's modeling NGN Routing revenues down by 8% sequentially, Newer Products down 10, Switching down 12%, Other Products down 5% and Services up 2%. But the dividend (forward yield 3.22%) may be reason enough to own, he says.
    • It's a tough quarter to forecast, says Credit Suisse's Kulbinder Garcha, but "expectations remain too high." Cisco had a 14-week quarter in fiscal Q3 2016, and Street estimates may be too high for the next quarter, he says. "Taking out the extra week, Street estimates are pointing to a revenue growth of ~6% Y/Y, which we believe is optimistic."
    • The company's had tough competition from Arista Networks (NYSE:ANET) and Juniper Networks (NYSE:JNPR), Garcha adds. Their strength shows an accelerated share shift is under way and means that "Cisco’s switching market position remains vulnerable, and switching revenues continued to decelerate."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:22 PM

  • RDC

    Rowan cold stacks one rig, retires pair in latest fleet status report

    • Rowan (RDC -3.1%) is lower after its latest fleet status report showed it had cold stacked one jack-up rig, sold two and received several extensions for several others.
    • RDC says the 1983-built jack-up Rowan California, which previously operated in the Middle East, was cold stacked, while the Rowan Gorilla II and Rowan Gorilla III, were sold during Q4.
    • RDC also says the Gilbert Rowe received a contract extension with Saudi Aramco at current rate until March 31, the Rowan Gorilla IV got a Gulf of Mexico contract extension for 10 months of work at a $65K dayrate, and the Rowan EXL III started operations in the Gulf of Mexico in mid-December for six months of work at a $55K dayrate.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:47 PM
  • TAP

    Susquehanna on why Molson Coors could run 42% higher

    • Susquehanna analyst Pablo Zuanic provides detailed analysis on how he derived a $141 price target (+42% upside) on Molson Coors (TAP -0.5%). Snippets from his note provided to Seeking Alpha are provided below.
    • "Our call is based on the potential for significant margin expansion potential at MillerCoors; we realize that without that upside, the buy-thesis does not work," he writes.
    • "Changes and investments in the brand portfolio make us think less money will be left on the table (with the consumer, retailer, and wholesaler) and that as such “yields” across the value chain will be just as important as the cost savings/synergy guidance (which we think is conservative) in delivering margin expansion," he adds.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:31 PM
  • HTZ

    Hedge fund love lifts Hertz Global

    • Hertz Global (NYSE:HTZ) is up 8.12% after Carl Icahn boosted his stake in the company by more than double to 29.3M shares.
    • Hertz was also a new buy at Saba Capital Management, according to the firm's 13F filing.
    • Shares of Hertz are at their highest level in over a month.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:25 PM | 10 Comments
  • AIG

    AIG still down 9%; ratings shoe to drop next?

    • via Ben Levisohn at Barron's
    • The previously announced Q4 reserve charge ended up coming in at $5.6B pretax, significantly larger than his estimate of $3B, says Barclays' Jay Gelb.
    • He's got his eye on A.M. Best - if the agency were to affirm its 'A' rating on AIG, it would remove a negative overhang. If, however, there's a downgrade to 'A-,' it could result in a slowdown or cessation of buybacks as the insurer looks to preserve capital
    • In a worst-case scenario, says Gelb, it a downgrade could require the need for a dilutive capital raise.
    • In one bit of good news, S&P last night said it would take no immediate rating action on AIG.
    • Previously: AIG plunges 9% after Q4 disappointment (Feb. 15)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:23 PM | 10 Comments
  • EDIT

    Editas prevails in CRISPR/Cas9 patent dispute with UC; shares rally 28%

    • Editas Medicine (EDIT +27.6%) jumps on a 4x surge in volume in response to the Broad Institute and MIT's patent win against the University of California related to gene editing technology CRISPR/Cas9. Editas is the commercial venture formed to monetize the patents.
    • The ruling by the Patent Trial and Appeal Board is a negative for Editas competitors Intellia Therapeutics (NTLA -11.1%) and Crisper Therapeutics (CRSP -27.2%), ventures formed to monetize the patents claimed by UC-Berkeley's Jennifer Doudna and French researcher Emmanuelle Charpentier.
    • Doudna and Charpentier are widely considered the discoverers of CRISPR/Cas9 who dutifully filed patent applications in the U.S. The Broad Institute filed later based on the work of Feng Zhang but claimed ownership of the patents based on Zhang's research records that appeared to show that he was the "first to discover."
    • CRISPR-Cas9 is the "next big thing" in biotech because of its unprecedented precision in editing DNA. CRISPR, the acronym for "clustered, regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats," uses RNA to guide the molecular scissors, the Cas9 enzyme, to a specific DNA sequence where it makes a specific cut in the DNA and triggers the cell's DNA repair machinery to address the genetic defect.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:07 PM | 36 Comments
  • DJCO

    AmEx buffeted by Munger comments

    • Speaking at a Daily Journal (NASDAQ:DJCO) meeting, Charlie Munger (BRK.A, BRK.B) says he's "confused" about the future of American Express (NYSE:AXP), according to a Bloomberg report.
    • AmEX investors are deluded if they think they know the payment industry's future, he adds.
    • AXP shares fell by more than $1 as the news hit the wires, but have recovered some of that since. They're now higher by 0.1%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:06 PM | 14 Comments

    KeyW started at Outperform at RBC Capital Markets

    • Analyst Matthew McConnell notes KeyW's (NASDAQ:KEYW) opportunity for share gains among untapped intelligence agencies, robust early contributions from improved business development investments and the company's potential to better margins on incremental revenues.
    • Considers a pure play on defense cybersecurity and intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance [ISR].
    • Price target $12 (current price $10.18, +3.25%).
     
     
     
     
    | 1:55 PM
  • CAI

    Container sector rallies off of positive read from CAI

    • Some positive comments from the CAI International (CAI +3.6%) conference call haven't gone unnoticed by investors.
    • "Many of the underlying trends that negatively affected the container industry has reversed over the past three quarters. Container prices have increased 60% from the lows experienced in early 2016 and currently stand at around $2,100 for a 20 foot container," noted CAI CEO Victor Garcia.
    • Textainer Group Holdings (TGH +10.8%) and Triton International (TRTN +0.9%) are both higher on the day.
    • Previously: CAI International misses by $0.22, misses on revenue (Feb. 14)
    • CAI conference call transcript
     
     
     
     
    | 1:36 PM
  • TU

    Telus moving forward with Manitoba expansion as BCE deal proceeds

    • Telus (TU -0.4%) is moving forward with an expansion in Manitoba, now that regulatory OKs have come in for BCE's (BCE +0.9%) acquision of Manitoba Telecom Services (OTCPK:MOBAF +4.8%).
    • Telus has a deal to take over nearly one-quarter of Manitoba Telecom's postpaid wireless customers, as well as 13 retail locations, for about C$300M.
    • A network-sharing arrangement is part of the deal, as is a gradual migration of customers to ease the transition, though the transaction is expected to close around April 1.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:35 PM
  • RDUS

    Shire still eyeing Radius Health, shares up 3%

    • Radius Health (RDUS +3.3%) perks up modestly higher volume on the rumor that Shire plc (SHPG +0.2%) is still interested in acquiring the biopharma firm according to a person close to the matter. Its purported interest was first reported in October 2016.
    • A deal could value Radius at $70 per share, although nothing is likely to happen prior to the FDA's March 30 action date for its review of the company's NDA for lead product candidate abaloparatide for osteoporosis.
    • Source: StreetInsider
     
     
     
     
    | 1:33 PM | 6 Comments
  • BG

    Bunge +10% on strong Q4; CEO says Trump talk has not disrupted trade

    • The flow of basic foodstuffs from U.S. farms to overseas markets has yet to be disrupted by Pres. Trump’s talk of trade overhauls, Bunge (BG +9.8%) CEO Soren Schroder says after his company easily beat analyst estimates for Q4 earnings and revenues.
    • While grain traders are watching for any signs of a shift arising from changes to U.S. trade policy, Schroder says "it's business as usual" as price and supply remain the dominant factor for companies such as BG and the governments and food companies purchasing U.S.-grown corn and other crops.
    • The CEO says BG’s Mexican flour mills have in the past shipped in wheat from Russia and Canada, and could do so again if U.S. trade policy changes affect the flow of U.S. grain into Mexico, but replacing other U.S. agricultural products such as soybean meal, largely shipped into Mexico by rail, would be more costly and could create logistical headaches for Mexican importers.
    • CFO Thomas Boehlert says large crops and expanding margins in South America should boost earnings in 2017, although the company expects the year to start off slow.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:29 PM
  • INSY

    Insys providing Cannabidiol Oral Solution in compassionate use epilepsy studies; shares ahead 13%

    • Insys Therapeutics (INSY +12.6%) perks up on double normal volume on the heels of its announcement that clinical investigators are continuing to provide its Cannabidiol Oral Solution on a no-cost compassionate use basis to children with treatment-resistant epilepsy who completed the 48-week safety study (15 kids so far).
    • “We are pleased that investigators have deemed it appropriate to continue patients on Cannabidiol Oral Solution beyond 48 weeks of treatment and we remain dedicated to making our product available to them,” said Dr. Santosh Vetticaden, Insys’ Interim CEO and Chief Medical Officer.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:16 PM | 16 Comments

  • WU

    PayPal shadow hangs over Western Union

    • The acquisition by PayPal of bill payments firm TIO Networks could be a competitive threat to Western Union (WU -0.1%), warns Morgan Stanley (source: Bloomberg).
    • PayPal bought Xoom last year in another deal that indicates payments competition with Western Union could heat up. There's also the Moneygram-Ant Financial tie-up to consider.
    • Previously: PayPal closes Xoom deal (Nov. 12, 2015)
    • Previously: PayPal acquiring TIO Networks for $233M (Feb. 14)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:34 PM
  • CLSN

    Celsion prices equity offering; shares slip 35%

    • Nano cap Celsion (CLSN -34.7%) slumps on a 24x surge in volume in response to the pricing of its public offering of ~21.7M shares of common stock at $0.23 per share. Buyers will also receive one five-year warrant to purchase 3/4 of a share of common at $0.23 with each share purchased. Closing date is February 21. Net proceeds will fund clinical trials, working capital and general corporate purposes.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:11 PM
  • PG

    Procter & Gamble at two-year high after Trian steps in

    • Procter & Gamble (PG +2.9%) trades at a two-year high after investors bet that the emergence of Trian as a +$3B stakeholder will ratchet up pressure on the company to cut costs.
    • Some investment firms also think the Trian factor brings the P&G break-up option back into the mix.
    • "While P&G has taken sensible steps to enhance shareholder value recently, the perceived value of a P&G break-up is likely to re-emerge," advises Jefferies analyst Kevin Grundy.
    • P&G traded as high as $91.10 before peeling back a bit.
    • Previously: Procter & Gamble +4% on report of big Trian stake (Feb. 14)

  • NVAX

    Novavax's mid-stage study of RSV vaccine candidate poised to start; shares ahead 18%

    • Novavax (NVAX +18.3%) is up on more than double normal volume. No particular news accounts for the action. Last month, it initiated a Phase 2 clinical trial assessing the safety and immunogenicity of its F-protein nanoparticle RSV F Vaccine in adults at least 60 years old.
    • The 300-subject study will evaluate the performance of one- and two-dose regimens of RSV F Vaccine with and without aluminum phosphate or the company's Matrix-M adjuvant. Top-line data are expected in Q3.
    • RSV infection is a significant risk for older people, affecting 2.5M Americans each year causing 207K hospitalizations and 16K deaths. There are currently no RSV vaccines commercially available.

    • There's nothing too new in Janet Yellen's 2nd day on Capital Hill. As with yesterday, she's giving off a more hawkish vibe than at least some may have expected. The 10-year Treasury yield is higher by three basis points to 2.50%, and Fed Funds futures are now pricing in nearly a 50% chance of a March rate hike (up from less than 25% a few days back).
    • The Fed boss is naturally offering a defense of the current regulatory regime, including the Volcker Rule and the CCAR, but the Trump administration, its now-confirmed Treasury Secretary and the leaders of key congressional committees are working to roll back much of Dodd-Frank.

  • LC

    LendingClub -9% after results; sell-side bull/bear react

    • A bullish Mark Palmer from BTIG blames the decline on a "sell the news" reaction following the stock's big move higher this year.
    • There's much to like, however, even beyond the headline earnings beat. Among the items is the company's first sequential increase in loan originations since the scandal that forced out the CEO in May 2016. Then there's the return of banks to LendingClub's (NYSE:LC) platform (funded 31% of originations vs. 13% in Q3), the importance of which "is difficult to overstate."
    • He reiterates his Buy rating and $9 price target.
    • Compass Point's Michael Tarkan doesn't share this bullishness, noting a Q/Q 24% rise in sales/marketing expense and just a 1% increase in originations. On a Y/Y basis, marketing expense rose 4% amid a 23% drop in originations.
    • He also notes the company continues to shed its lower-quality borrowing base through tighter underwriting. Tarkan reiterates his Sell rating and $4 price target.
    • Shares -9.1% premarket to $6.
    • Previously: Investors sell the news after LendingClub beats (Feb. 14)

  • ARDX

    Ardelyx selectively reports results from late-stage study to show treatment effect of lead product candidate tenapanor in ESRD patients with elevated serum phosphate

    • Ardelyx (NASDAQ:ARDX) announces "successful" results from a Phase 3 clinical trial assessing lead product candidate tenapanor in patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) with hyperphosphatemia (elevated serum phosphate).
    • Restricting its analysis to responders (defined as those showing at least a 1.2 mg/dL drop in serum phosphate after the initial eight-week treatment period) (n=80/164), there was a statistically significant difference in the pooled treatment group compared to placebo in the re-randomized four-week withdrawal period. The results imply that 51% (n=84/164) of the participants failed to respond during the eight-week initial treatment period.
    • The main reported adverse event was diarrhea (39%), including 17 (7.8%) treatment discontinuations.
    • The company plans to initiate another Phase 3 study by mid-year with a similar protocol. Data from the first study will be presented at the American Society of Nephrology Kidney Week in early November.
    • Shares are up 2% premarket on turnover of 1,000 shares.
    • Previously: Efficacy of Ardelyx's tenapanor looks shaky in mid-stage study ESRD study after primary endpoint changed (June 22, 2016)
